bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 166, Number 44 (Thursday, March 5, 2020)][House]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. TIMMONS:H.J. Res. 86.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article V of the Constitution: The Congress, whenever twothirds of both houses shall deem it necessary, shall proposeamendments to this Constitution, or, on the application ofthe legislatures of two thirds of the several states, shallcall a convention for proposing amendments, which, in eithercase, shall be valid to all intents and purposes, as part ofthis Constitution, when ratified by the legislatures of threefourths of the several states, or by conventions in threefourths thereof, as the one or the other mode of ratificationmay be proposed by the Congress; provided that no amendmentwhich may be made prior to the year one thousand eighthundred and eight shall in any manner affect the first andfourth clauses in the ninth section of the first article; andthat no state, without its consent, shall be deprived of itsequal suffrage in the Senate.[Page H1537]

item.text: Referred to the House Committee on the Judiciary.

summary.text:
This joint resolution proposes a constitutional amendment prohibiting a person from serving more than two consecutive terms as a Senator or six consecutive terms as a Representative.

Terms beginning before the ratification of this article do not count towards consecutive term limits.

bill.title: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to limit the number of consecutive terms that a Member of Congress may serve.

item.title: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to limit the number of consecutive terms that a Member of Congress may serve.
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to limit the number of consecutive terms that a Member of Congress may serve.

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on the Judiciary.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
